Vegetarian foods that are good sources of vitamin D - The Times of India
summary:
Vegetarian Foods that are Good Sources of Vitamin D

Date: Jan 11, 2025 Source: Times of India

This article discusses various vegetarian foods that are excellent sources of vitamin D, addressing the importance of this vitamin for health, especially for bone health and immune function.

  • Fortified plant-based foods such as fortified milk.
  • Mushrooms, specifically providing modest amounts of vitamin D.
  • Fortified cereals paired with plant-based milk.
  • Plant-based yogurts that are fortified with vitamin D.
  • Tofu and tempeh as versatile and nutritious options.
  • Fortified orange juice as a refreshing start to the day.
  • Dairy products like milk and cheese as nutrient-rich choices.
  • Vitamin D supplements that are vegetarian-friendly.
“Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and immune function.”

The article emphasizes that for vegetarians, there are multiple delicious options available to ensure adequate vitamin D intake.
newTitle: Vegetarian Foods Rich in Vitamin D

China marks muted 5th anniversary of first 'death' from the disease that killed 7 million and changed wor - The Times of India
First HMPV case in Dibrugarh: Doctors reassure public, cite no significant threat - The Statesman
summary:
First HMPV Case in Dibrugarh: Doctors Reassure Public, Cite No Significant Threat

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Statesman

After the first reported case of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in Dibrugarh, doctors and health officials have reassured the public that the virus poses no significant threat.

  • The case was identified in a child at Assam Medical College and Hospital (AMCH).
  • The ICMR confirmed the presence of HMPV in the sample sent for testing.
  • 110 cases of HMPV have been reported in the region since 2014.
  • HMPV primarily affects the respiratory system, particularly in children, older adults, and immunocompromised individuals.
  • Infections are typically mild and self-limiting, with most patients recovering without specialized treatment.
“While there is no immediate danger, enhancing awareness and improving medical facilities will ensure better response mechanisms in the future,” said Dr Borkakoty.

HMPV, first identified in 2001, is transmitted through respiratory droplets, direct contact, or contaminated surfaces.
newTitle: First HMPV Case Reported in Dibrugarh, Doctors Alleviate Public Concerns

title: Gujarat Registers Two More HMPV Cases, Infection Count Rises To Five - News18
Staying healthy this winter in America: Tips to avoid Norovirus, Covid-19, Flu, and RSV - India Today
summary:
Staying Healthy This Winter: Tips to Avoid Norovirus, COVID-19, Flu, and RSV

Published On: Jan 11, 2025

Source: indiatodayglobal

As winter approaches, the risk of illnesses like Covid-19, flu, norovirus, and RSV increases due to more indoor gatherings and harsher weather affecting our defenses. This article offers guidance on recognizing symptoms and preventive measures.

  • Norovirus spreads through contaminated food and surfaces, causing gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • The common cold presents mild respiratory symptoms.
  • Flu symptoms are more intense and can last longer than cold symptoms.
  • Covid-19 can exhibit a wide range of symptoms including fever and loss of taste.
  • RSV primarily affects young children, presenting similar symptoms to a cold.

Key Preventive Measures Include:

  • Regular hand washing with soap.
  • Cleaning surfaces frequently.
  • Avoiding face touching.
  • Staying home if sick.
  • Considering vaccines where applicable.
“If you do get sick, prompt testing can help determine whether you have Covid-19 or influenza.”

Protective behaviors, such as hand hygiene and responsible sick days, are vital to minimize the spread of these winter illnesses.
newTitle: Staying Healthy This Winter: Tips to Avoid Norovirus, COVID-19, Flu, and RSV

title: 9-month old tests positive for HMPV in Gujarat, cases rise to four in state - Business Standard
summary:
9-Month-Old Tests Positive for HMPV in Gujarat, Bringing Cases to Four

Last Updated: Jan 11 2025 | Source: Press Trust of India

Gujarat has reported its fourth case of human metapneumovirus (HMPV) with a nine-month-old child contracting the infection. The cases have been confirmed in less than a week.

  • The infant was admitted to a private hospital on January 6 with respiratory symptoms.
  • Prior confirmed cases include an 80-year-old man and an 8-year-old boy.
  • The state's first case involved a two-month-old boy from Rajasthan.
  • HMPV spreads via respiratory droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces.
"HMPV is closely related to the Respiratory Syncytial Virus and, like it, affects the respiratory tract."

This recent rise in cases highlights the need for awareness and precautionary measures against HMPV in the community.
newTitle: 9-Month-Old Tests Positive for HMPV in Gujarat, Bringing Cases to Four

title: Olive oil is healthy. Turns out olive leaf extract may be good for us too - The Indian Express
summary:
Olive oil is healthy. Turns out olive leaf extract may be good for us too

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Indian Express

Olive oil has well-documented health benefits, linked to heart disease and other conditions. Recent studies suggest olive leaf extract may also offer health advantages, particularly in managing blood pressure and cholesterol levels.

  • Olive leaves are rich in the antioxidant oleuropein, which is higher in greener leaves.
  • Reviews show olive leaf extract may help reduce blood pressure and improve blood lipids.
  • Effects vary based on dosage and duration of use—more research needed for clarity.
  • Olive leaves can be consumed in different ways, including brewed as tea or added to foods.
  • No toxicity reported with recommended doses; caution for pregnant or breastfeeding women.
“If you have high blood pressure, diabetes or raised blood lipids you may see some benefit from taking olive leaf extract.”

The potential benefits of olive leaf extract for health need further research to establish consistent effects. Consulting a doctor before starting supplementation is advised.
newTitle: Olive Oil and Leaf Extract: Health Benefits Explored

title: HMPV detected in 10-month-old baby in India's Assam - Xinhua
Mumps outbreak triggers school closure and heightened surveillance in Alappuzha - The Hindu
summary:
Mumps Outbreak Leads to School Closures and Increased Surveillance in Alappuzha

Published on: January 11, 2025 06:32 pm IST

The Health department has ramped up surveillance and preventive measures due to a mumps outbreak in Alappuzha, resulting in the closure of two schools for 21 days.

  • Two schools closed: Government NS Lower Primary School and Government Lower Primary School.
  • 23 students from Eramalloor school and 9 from Perumbalam South have tested positive.
  • Previous closure due to 33 positive cases at another school last month.
  • Precautionary measures are being implemented in collaboration with local bodies.
  • K.C. Venugopal, MP, requests government action for testing and awareness programs.
“Despite being a vaccine-preventable disease, mumps was not included in the Universal Immunisation Programme.” - K.C. Venugopal

The mumps virus can lead to serious complications if untreated, and health officials encourage the public to seek medical advice for symptoms.
newTitle: Mumps Outbreak Leads to School Closures and Increased Surveillance in Alappuzha

title: Winter illnesses: Tips to protect yourself from norovirus, Covid-19, flu and RSV - Hindustan Times
summary:
Winter illnesses: Tips to protect yourself from norovirus, Covid-19, flu and RSV

Date: Jan 11, 2025   Source: Hindustan Times

This article highlights the rise of various winter illnesses and offers tips on how to protect against them.

  • Washing hands thoroughly to reduce the spread of viruses.
  • Cleaning surfaces regularly to prevent contamination.
  • Avoiding touching the face to minimize infection risk.
  • Considering vaccinations where available.
  • Staying home if sick to prevent spreading illness.
“It's best to regularly clean surfaces that you come into a lot of contact with. Think doorknobs, light switches, countertops.”

Implementing these strategies can help maintain health during the peak of winter illnesses.
newTitle: Tips to Protect Yourself from Winter Illnesses like Norovirus, Covid-19, Flu, and RSV

The best time of day to drink coffee for maximum benefits isn’t first thing when you wake up - Fortune
summary:
The Best Time to Drink Coffee for Maximum Health Benefits

Publication Date: Not provided
Source: Fortune

Recent studies suggest that drinking coffee at certain times of the day can significantly affect health and longevity.

  • 81% of American coffee drinkers have their cup with breakfast.
  • Morning coffee drinkers have a reduced risk of death and cardiovascular disease compared to all-day drinkers.
  • Experts recommend consuming coffee between 9:30 a.m. and 11 a.m. for optimal effects.
  • Caffeine can disrupt sleep if consumed too late in the day.
  • Some individuals experience adverse effects from coffee if consumed too soon after waking.
“Everybody has been at that point where their eyes are bugging out of their head, and they are jittery and unfocused.” - Julia Zumpano

In conclusion, the timing of coffee consumption can influence its health benefits, and adjustments may be necessary based on individual responses and schedules.
newTitle: The Best Time to Drink Coffee for Maximum Health Benefits

title: Ice bath for stress? Study says 10-minute cold-water immersion could be the key to sharper mind, better sleep - Hindustan Times
summary:
Ice bath benefits: Here's how cold-water immersion could transform your sleep and mental clarity.

Publication Date: Jan 11, 2025
Source: Hindustan Times

Cold-water immersion (CWI) has been celebrated for its recovery benefits. A recent study reveals it may sharpen cognitive performance, improve sleep, and ease mental worries.

Main Points:

  • Study Overview: Conducted by University of Central Lancashire, involving 13 participants.
  • Key Findings: Significant improvements in cognitive tasks, better sleep quality, and reduced worry among participants.
  • Caution: Not safe for everyone, particularly those with certain health conditions.
“Cold-water immersion helps with sleep, particularly during periods of pronounced sleep disturbances,” noted lead researcher Robert Allan.

This study highlights the potential of cold-water immersion as a tool for enhancing cognitive well-being and sleeping patterns.
newTitle: Ice Bath Benefits: Study Links Cold-Water Immersion to Better Sleep and Mental Clarity

title: Public health professionals need to communicate proactively to avoid concerns: experts on HMPV - The Hindu
summary:
Public health professionals need to communicate proactively to avoid concerns: experts on HMPV

Date: January 11, 2025 | Source: The Hindu

The need for public health professionals to proactively reach out to people with correct information was emphasized during a webinar focused on Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV).

  • The webinar aimed to distinguish fact from fiction surrounding HMPV.
  • Soumya Swaminathan highlighted the importance of scientific literacy to prevent panic over HMPV information.
  • Bernhard Schwartländer stressed the need for proactive communication rather than reactive responses to misinformation.
  • HMPV is not a new virus; it is common among children and generally causes mild respiratory illnesses.
  • Experts discussed the 'One Health' approach to address emerging viruses that can jump from animals to humans.
“It is no good to wait for the public to be concerned about information circulating on social media platforms when it is very difficult to then actually overcome it.” - Bernhard Schwartländer

The discussion underscored the importance of being prepared for future viral threats and establishing resilient healthcare systems.
newTitle: Public health experts advocate proactive communication on HMPV concerns

title: 28-Year-Old Cambodian Man Dies From H5N1 Avian Influenza - TheHealthSite
summary:
28-Year-Old Cambodian Man Dies Of H5N1 Avian Influenza

Date & Source: January 10, 2023, The Health Site

A 28-year-old man from Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, has died from an H5N1 avian flu infection after likely being exposed to infected chickens.

  • This is the 19th confirmed human case of H5N1 in Cambodia since early 2023.
  • The previous case involved a teenage girl who died from a new reassortant strain in September 2024.
  • The deceased experienced fever, breathing difficulties, cough, and fatigue before passing away.
  • The patient’s family raises chickens, and he was involved in caring for and cooking sick birds.
“Cambodian officials have not yet provided information on which clade is involved in this case.”

This incident highlights ongoing health risks associated with H5N1 avian influenza in the region.
newTitle: 28-Year-Old Cambodian Man Dies From H5N1 Avian Influenza

title: China marks muted 5th anniversary of first Covid death - The Hindu
summary:
China Marks Fifth Anniversary of First Covid Death with Little Acknowledgment

Date: January 11, 2025 Source: The Hindu

The fifth anniversary of the first known Covid-19 death went unnoticed in China, with no memorials or public discussions on the date.

  • The anniversary marks the death of a 61-year-old man in Wuhan on January 11, 2020, due to the unknown virus that led to the global pandemic.
  • Despite over seven million deaths worldwide, the event lacked significant acknowledgment in China’s media or social platforms.
  • China's ruling Communist Party maintains tight control over discussions related to the pandemic, recently dropping its zero-Covid policy.
  • Little is known about the identity of the first Covid casualty, who was linked to a seafood market in Wuhan.
  • Accusations against China from Western governments persist regarding the handling and reporting of the virus's origins and spread.
“Dr. Li, another year has gone by. How quickly time passes.”

China's lack of commemorations highlights the sensitivity surrounding the pandemic within the country, contrasting with more visible acknowledgments elsewhere.
newTitle: China Marks Fifth Anniversary of First Covid Death with Little Acknowledgment

Multi-country outbreak of mpox, External situation report #45 - 11 January 2025 - World Health Organization
summary:
Multi-country outbreak of mpox, External situation report #45 - 11 January 2025

Date: 11 January 2025 | Source: WHO Emergency Situational Updates

This is the 45th situation report for the multi-country outbreak of mpox, which provides details on the latest epidemiological trends. The outbreak of clade Ib monkeypox virus (MPXV) continues predominantly in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Burundi and Uganda, with new travel-related cases identified in previously unaffected countries.

  • The outbreak is largely centered in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Burundi, and Uganda.
  • New travel-related cases have been reported in unaffected countries.
  • Strengthened surveillance and timely reporting is necessary to prevent international spread.
“Recent travel-associated mpox cases highlight the risk of undetected transmission.”

The situation underscores the importance of global monitoring and improving surveillance systems against mpox.
newTitle: Multi-country Outbreak of Mpox: Situation Report #45 - January 11, 2025

Assam reports first HMPV case this season as 10-month-old child tests positive in Dibrugarh - Hindustan Times
summary:
Assam Reports First Case of HMPV Infection This Season

Date: Jan 11, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

Assam has reported its first case of human metapneumovirus (HMPV) infection this season, with a 10-month-old child testing positive. The infant is currently undergoing treatment at Assam Medical College and Hospital (AMCH) in Dibrugarh and is said to be stable.

  • Ten-month-old child tests positive for HMPV in Dibrugarh, Assam.
  • Child admitted to AMCH with cold-related symptoms four days ago.
  • HMPV infection confirmed by ICMR-RMRC Lahowal after routine tests.
  • HMPV is a common respiratory virus that usually causes mild symptoms.
  • Similar HMPV cases reported in Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu.
“The HMPV infection was confirmed yesterday after we got test results from Lahowal-based ICMR-RMRC. The child is stable now. It is a common virus, and there is nothing to worry about.” - Dr. Dhrubajyoti Bhuyan, AMCH superintendent

The detection of HMPV is not unusual, as the virus circulates seasonally and typically impacts infants and individuals with weaker immune systems more severely.
newTitle: Assam Reports First Case of HMPV Infection This Season

title: Here's how much exercise you really need to stay healthy if you're sitting all day at the office; read - Hindustan Times
‘Drink your coffee, but only in the morning’: What a new study says - The Indian Express
summary:
‘Drink your coffee, but only in the morning’: What a new study says

Publication Date: January 8, 2025
Source: Indian Express

A new study indicates that drinking coffee in the mornings provides significant health benefits compared to later consumption. The study, involving over 42,000 adults, highlights the timing of coffee consumption as a crucial factor in health outcomes.

  • Morning coffee drinkers are 16% less likely to die from any cause.
  • They are also 31% less likely to die from cardiovascular disease than those who do not consume coffee.
  • The study does not show significant mortality reduction for all-day drinkers compared to non-drinkers.
  • Health benefits are observed irrespective of the amount of coffee consumed in the morning.
  • Other research suggests caffeine can disrupt sleep if consumed too late in the day, potentially impacting health.
“It’s not just whether you drink coffee or how much you drink, but the time of day when you drink coffee that’s important.” - Lu Qi, Tulane University

This study could influence coffee consumption habits, encouraging people to enjoy coffee earlier in the day for better health outcomes.
newTitle: Health Benefits Linked to Morning Coffee Consumption, Study Reveals
